stories.text: Yesterday was our school sports day. My best friend, Leo, is a great runner and he wanted to be the **champion** of the 100-meter race. He practiced very hard for weeks, showing great **dedication** to his training. During the race, he was leading, but suddenly he felt a sharp pain in his leg. It was a serious **injury** that made him **collapse** on the track. The schoolâ€™s **medical** team ran to help him immediately. Although he didnâ€™t win a **medal** this time, we were all very proud of him.

Local runner Sarah Miller was the favorite to become the race **champion** this morning. However, halfway through, an old wall began to **collapse** near the track due to a minor earthquake. Sarah stopped running to help an elderly spectator who had suffered a head **injury** from falling debris. She stayed until the **medical** staff arrived. Even though she finished last, the committee awarded her a special **medal** for her bravery. They praised her **dedication** to the community.

What truly defines a professional athlete? Is it the shiny gold **medal** hanging on the wall, or the title of world **champion**? While these are symbols of success, they are merely the results of years of invisible **dedication**. Athletes often push their bodies to the absolute limit, sometimes to the point where their physical systems **collapse** under the pressure. When a career-threatening **injury** occurs, it is not just a physical challenge. Beyond the reach of modern **medical** science, it is the athleteâ€™s inner will that determines if they can return.

Behind the roaring cheers lies a grueling reality. To pursue an Olympic **medal**, one must surrender everything. This level of **dedication** is often romanticized, yet it borders on obsession. We witness elite sprinters whose world-class forms suddenly **collapse** in the final meters, victims of immense physiological strain. Often, a single **injury** is all it takes to derail a decade of preparation, rendering one a former **champion** overnight. While the **medical** interventions available today are sophisticated, they cannot always mend a shattered dream.

My piano concert was a big **success** last night. Before I went on stage, I was so nervous and felt a little **pain** in my stomach. However, I saw you in the crowd and felt your **support**. It gave me the **courage** to play my best. The music was very **emotional**, and some people even cried. After the show, the theater **staff** told me I did a great job.

Nurses often see patients in great physical **pain**, which can be very **emotional** for everyone involved. To keep going, the hospital **staff** need a lot of **courage** and mental strength to face life and death. They also rely on the **support** of their colleagues to get through long, tiring shifts. When a patient finally recovers and goes home, it is considered a wonderful **success** for the entire team.

Many legendary leaders have experienced the **pain** of losing everything before reaching the top. What keeps them moving is often the **emotional** connection they have with their mission. It takes true **courage** to admit when a plan has failed and to try again. Moreover, the **support** from a dedicated team is crucial, as no one can achieve greatness alone. Ultimately, even a small group of **staff** members can change the world. Their grit is the real secret to long-term **success**.

Resilience requires a highly trained **staff** capable of maintaining focus during extreme volatility. When an industry faces a downturn, the psychological **pain** experienced by employees can lead to burnout. Therefore, providing robust **support** systems is a strategic necessity. Leaders must exhibit the professional **courage** to make unpopular decisions for long-term stability. Such high-pressure environments are inevitably **emotional**, yet they serve as the ultimate litmus test for institutional **success**.

Yesterday, Sam saw a cat stuck in a tall tree. The cat began to **struggle** to get down. Sam knew he had to help **immediately**, so he started to climb. He needed all his **strength** to reach the branch. When he finally brought the cat down safely, all the neighbors looked at him with **admiration**. Samâ€™s parents felt great **pride** in their son. Now, everyone in the street gives Sam a lot of **respect**.

From the start, the steep path was a constant **struggle** for my tired legs. I soon realized that I had underestimated the physical **strength** required for this altitude. When a thick fog rolled in, our guide told us to stop **immediately**. As I looked up at the snowy peak, I felt a deep sense of **admiration** for the professional climbers. They certainly deserve our **respect**. Although I didn't reach the top, I still take **pride** in how high I climbed.

Eleanor Vance dedicated her life to the **struggle** for social justice. Whenever she witnessed unfairness, she would react **immediately** by organizing a protest. Her unwavering moral **strength** allowed her to face powerful opponents without fear. Over the decades, she earned the **respect** of world leaders and citizens alike. Today, visitors express their **admiration** for her sacrifices. Her story remains a source of national **pride**.

In moments of crisis, the ego must be set aside so that one can respond **immediately** to the dictates of conscience. This requires a rare form of inner **strength** that is cultivated through years of reflection. We do not grant our **respect** to those who simply succeed, but to those who maintain their integrity while experiencing a deep **struggle**. Such resilience evokes a profound **admiration** that transcends boundaries. Ultimately, a healthy sense of **pride** is born from the knowledge that one has remained upright.

story.text: The pursuit of athletic excellence is a grueling path paved with paradoxical trials. To eventually emerge as a world **champion**, one must possess a level of **dedication** that borders on the ascetic, sacrificing years for the singular hope of an Olympic **medal**. Yet, a sudden, debilitating **injury** can render a lifetime of preparation moot. When the physical framework begins to **collapse** under immense physiological pressure, the presence of an elite **medical** team is indispensable. The **emotional** toll of a failed campaign is often far more corrosive than the visceral **pain** of a torn ligament. In these dark corridors of defeat, the unwavering **support** of a loyal coaching **staff** becomes the only tether to one's former identity. It requires a rare species of **courage** to find the inner **strength** to rise from the ashes. The ensuing **struggle** to reclaim one's status is a psychological quest to regain self-**respect**. One must act **immediately** to prevent cynicism from taking root, replacing despair with a quiet **pride** in the resilience of the soul. Those who navigate this journey evoke a profound **admiration** from the global community, proving that true **success** is an enduring testament to the indomitable heart.

stories.text: Our principal made an **announcement** this morning about the school cafeteria. He said that some students did **research** to find out what we like to eat. **normally**, we eat chicken or pork, but many students want more **flavor** in their meals. In **comparison** with last year, the food is now much healthier. However, the cooks say it is sometimes hard to **distinguish** between the different spices. We must read the salt amounts **accurately** to make the food taste better.

I recently read an official **announcement** about a new smart kitchen scale. According to the company's **research**, most home cooks fail to measure spices **accurately**. In **comparison** with traditional scales, this one can **distinguish** between over 500 different types of powder. While I **normally** just guess the amounts, this device helps me add the perfect **flavor** to every dish I make. It is a great tool for anyone who loves cooking.

New **research** into the psychology of taste suggests that our environment affects us more than we realize. Scientists **normally** focus on the tongue, but a recent **announcement** highlights the role of sound. In **comparison** with quiet rooms, noisy places make it harder for people to **distinguish** subtle notes in their food. To **accurately** measure this effect, volunteers ate the same meal in different settings. They found that a loud background can significantly reduce the perceived **flavor** of a dessert.

Today's lecture focuses on the sensory **comparison** between virtual and physical reality. While we **normally** perceive the world through a blend of five senses, digital interfaces often fail to **distinguish** the nuances of smell and touch. Recent **research** has led to an **announcement** of a new 'e-tongue' technology. This device can **accurately** simulate any **flavor** by using controlled electrical pulses. This breakthrough may redefine how we experience culinary arts.

Last week, I was a **passenger** on a big bus to the mountains. The driver told us that the high altitude might **affect** our breathing. He said that if we feel **pressure** in our ears, we should swallow some water. It is important not to let the loud music **distract** us from the beautiful view outside. Some signs on the bus **indicate** where the emergency exits are. We should not **blame** the driver if the bus moves slowly on the steep hills, as the engine must **function** properly.

Did you know that stress can **affect** your body in many ways? When you are under a lot of **pressure**, your brain might not **function** as well as it usually does. Some studies **indicate** that constant noise can **distract** you from deep sleep. People often **blame** their coffee for their headaches, but it might actually be a lack of water. As a frequent **passenger** on long-distance flights, I have learned that staying hydrated is the best way to feel good.

In modern offices, the constant flow of emails can easily **distract** employees from their core tasks. Many workers **blame** technology for their lack of focus, but the problem is often deeper. Research results **indicate** that high levels of social **pressure** can negatively **affect** mental health. If a team is to **function** effectively, leaders must ensure that every **passenger** on the corporate journey feels valued. This environment reduces anxiety and boosts productivity.

The efficiency of public transit systems can significantly **affect** the economic growth of a city. When a subway line fails to **function** during peak hours, every **passenger** suffers from lost time. Data from recent surveys **indicate** that overcrowding can **distract** commuters and increase their stress levels. City officials often **blame** outdated infrastructure, but the intense **pressure** from rapid population growth is the primary driver.

I tried a new **recipe** for chocolate cake yesterday. The most important **ingredient** is dark chocolate. My mom had to **warn** me not to use too much sugar. I hope the kitchen can **remain** clean while I work! To **provide** a sweet taste, I added some honey. The baking **conditions** were perfect, and the smell was very **pleasant**. My family said this cake was the best **solution** for our hungry stomachs!

Finding a **pleasant** place to stay during your holiday is crucial. I recommend the Sunset Hotel because they **provide** excellent service to all guests. The hotel staff will **warn** you about the weather **conditions** before you go hiking. If you are looking for a **solution** to your stress, their spa is the perfect choice. You should also try their famous seafood soup; the secret **ingredient** is fresh ginger. Even after many years, the hotel's high quality has managed to **remain** the same.

To protect our oceans, we must find a long-term **solution** to plastic pollution. Scientists **warn** that if current **conditions** do not change, there will be more plastic than fish by 2050. Many companies now **provide** eco-friendly packaging as a better alternative. However, for these efforts to **remain** effective, we need global cooperation. Every single **ingredient** in our industrial products should be evaluated. Following a 'green **recipe**' for manufacturing is a necessity for a **pleasant** future.

In the competitive hospitality industry, the ability to **provide** a consistent and **pleasant** customer experience is paramount. When economic **conditions** fluctuate, businesses must find a creative **solution** to maintain their market share. Experts **warn** against cutting costs by reducing the quality of a core **ingredient** in the service model. Instead, companies should ensure that their values **remain** central to their operations. A successful business **recipe** involves a delicate balance.

story.text: The aviation industryâ€™s recent **announcement** regarding enhanced dining protocols has sparked a fascinating **comparison** between tradition and innovation. Extensive **research** into high-altitude physiology continues to **indicate** that an airplane cabin is an environment where our biological systems do not **function** as they **normally** do. For a start, the low humidity and **pressure** significantly **affect** our olfactory senses, making it difficult to **distinguish** between subtle notes in a complex dish. Consequently, food that would be considered delicious on the ground can often **remain** disappointingly bland in the sky. To **accurately** address this, airlines must **provide** a culinary **solution** that accounts for these unique **conditions**. Chefs often **warn** that a standard **recipe** must be modified, frequently adding more seasoning or a savory **ingredient** like tomato or mushroom to boost the **flavor**. However, even the most meticulously prepared cuisine can fail if a **passenger** is constantly unsettled. The persistent noise of the engines can **distract** the mind, further numbing the tongueâ€™s sensitivity to sweetness and salt. We cannot simply **blame** the catering staff for a mediocre meal when the very laws of physics are working against them. Ultimately, achieving a **pleasant** dining experience at thirty thousand feet is a triumph of both science and art.

champion.definition: the winner of a sports event or a competition
champion.example: Howard will be crowned the world chess champion after winning the final next Monday.

dedication.definition: the time, effort, and hard work one puts into achieving a certain goal
dedication.example: Doctor Parker shows total dedication to this project. She has spent a lot of time doing detailed studies since she began the project two years ago.

dedicate.definition: to give a lot of your time and effort to a particular activity
dedicate.example: For eighteen months, this author has dedicated himself to writing a book about the snacks available in Taiwanese night markets.

medal.definition: awarded to someone that has won a race or competition
medal.example: Liz dreamed of coming in first in the race and wearing a shiny gold medal around her neck.

injury.definition: physical damage or harm done to one's body
injury.example: After suffering a serious injury in her last race, the cyclist has no chance of becoming a world champion this time.

injure.definition: to harm yourself or somebody else physically
injure.example: Harry badly injured himself at the beach and was taken to the hospital.

success.definition: the fact that someone achieves something very well
success.example: Monica had great success in her work and became a famous singer after years of dedication.

succeed.definition: to achieve something that you have been trying to do
succeed.example: Despite having faced many difficulties, Kevin still succeeded in starting his own company.

successful.definition: achieving your aims or what was intended
successful.example: If you want to be successful in your job, work hard and never give up.

pain.definition: what you feel when you are hurt, injured, or sick
pain.example: Alex experienced a sharp pain in his leg while hiking.

painful.definition: causing you physical or emotional pain
painful.example: Meg's right arm was injured last week and thus she found carrying heavy things a bit painful.

painfully.definition: in a way that causes you physical or emotional pain
painfully.example: In spite of her sore wrist, Mrs. Davis painfully turned the tight handle until the door opened.

immediately.example: I need to leave immediately, or I'll miss my plane.

immediate.example: Upon getting the call, the police took immediate action and quickly arrived at the scene of the crime.

collapse.definition: to fall down, especially when one faints or feels weak
collapse.example: The woman felt dizzy after the seven-hour train journey and suddenly collapsed in the station.

medical.definition: related to the study and treatment of injury
medical.example: Lisa plans to attend medical school and become a doctor in the future.

staff.definition: a group or team of workers or employees
staff.example: The hotel staff greets all guests in a polite way.

courage.definition: the ability to face a difficult situation
courage.example: It takes courage for first-time swimmers to put their heads under the water.

strength.definition: will power or courage under challenging conditions
strength.example: It's important for a player to have enough mental strength to handle the stress during competitions.

strengthen.definition: to make someone or something stronger
strengthen.example: Spending holidays together greatly strengthens the bond between Henry and his family.

support.example: The crowd cheered loudly to show their support for the tennis player every time she won a point.

struggle.definition: to move with difficulty / a hard fight
struggle.example: With a heavy load in back, the truck struggled slowly up the steep hill.

pride.example: Neil took pride in his brother's determination when he saw him complete the marathon.

proud.definition: feeling pleased about something you have done
proud.example: Laura's parents were proud of her excellent score in science class.

emotional.example: Mr. Jones got very emotional and struggled to hold back the tears when his daughter graduated from law school.

emotion.definition: a strong feeling such as love, fear, or anger
emotion.example: Danny is shy, so it's hard for him to express his emotions and let others know how he feels.

admiration.example: Fans showed their admiration for the amazing actor by throwing flowers up onto the stage after the show.

admire.definition: to respect and admire someone or something
admire.example: Debbie deeply admires Jimmy for his generosity and honesty.

respect.definition: admiration for one's qualities, experience, or achievements
respect.example: Mike had great respect for the wise old man and always treated him politely.

warn.definition: to tell or remind someone about possible danger or problems
warn.example: Bill's parents warned him not to go mountain climbing because a strong typhoon was coming.

warning.definition: an official statement that tells people about a possible danger
warning.example: The moment the fire department issued a warning that the building might collapse, everyone inside got out immediately.

announcement.definition: an official statement, spoken or written, to inform people of an event or decision
announcement.example: Our English teacher made an announcement that there would be a test on Thursday.

announce.definition: to make a public or official statement
announce.example: This world champion boxer has announced that he will retire at the end of March.

research.definition: a detailed and careful study of a particular issue or problem
research.example: Dr. Smith is doing some research into how dolphins communicate with each other.

flavor.example: The soup has no flavor. You should add some salt to it.

flavoring.definition: a substance used to give flavor to food or drink
flavoring.example: Lucy prefers foods that don't have any added flavoring.

pressure.definition: the force produced by a liquid or gas within a container or limited space
pressure.example: Doctors often warn patients with high blood pressure to avoid high-fat diets.

normally.example: Uncle Frank normally reads the newspaper over breakfast, but this morning he watched the news on TV instead.

normal.example: It is normal for cats to sleep twelve to sixteen hours a day.

distinguish.definition: to identify two or more things or people as being different
distinguish.example: Nancy and her twin sister look so similar that even their parents can't distinguish between them sometimes.

accurately.definition: correctly; without error, doubt, or guessing
accurately.example: So far scientists have not found a way to predict earthquakes accurately.

accurate.definition: correct and true in every detail
accurate.example: Steve had his watch fixed because it was not accurate in telling time.

function.definition: to operate in a useful way / the purpose that something has
function.example: Malcolm's favorite couch also functions as a bed when one of his friends stays over for the night.

blame.definition: to see someone or something as the reason for a problem or accident
blame.example: The police blamed the drunken driver for the terrible car accident.

affect.definition: to cause someone or something to change in some way
affect.example: Global warming has greatly affected the lives of many wild animals, such as polar bears.

passenger.definition: someone in a vehicle, except for the driver
passenger.example: Passengers on the plane were glad to hear the captain announce that the strong winds wouldn't affect their flight.

distract.definition: to take someone's attention away from what he or she is supposed to be doing
distract.example: Ken tried to finish the novel before bed, but the loud music from next door kept distracting him from his reading.

distraction.definition: something that stops you from paying attention
distraction.example: With so many distractions, Tina found it difficult to study at home.

indicate.example: Recent research clearly indicates that only 3% of the children in this country get as much daily exercise as they should.

indication.definition: a sign that something exists, is true, or is likely to happen
indication.example: When people have a sore throat and a runny nose, it is normally an indication that they have the flu or a cold.

conditions.definition: the situation or environment that affects someone or something
conditions.example: Under normal conditions, my scooter functions well, but yesterday it was so cold that it wouldn't start.

condition.definition: the state that something is in
condition.example: My father has been driving the same car for twenty years, but it is still in good condition.

solution.definition: a way to solve a problem
solution.example: The government is trying to think of a solution to the problem of air pollution.

solve.definition: to find an answer to a problem
solve.example: We can solve the problem of garbage by recycling and reusing the things we have.

ingredient.definition: one of the foods used to prepare a certain dish
ingredient.example: This restaurant only uses natural ingredients like fruits, vegetables, and herbs in its dishes.

recipe.definition: a list of the ingredients for a dish, and instructions on how to prepare it
recipe.example: Does this cookbook include a recipe for apple pie?

comparison.definition: checking to see how two or more people or things are similar or different
comparison.example: The cost of living in Taipei is quite high. By comparison, it doesn't cost so much to live in any other city in Taiwan.

compare.definition: to examine people or things to see how they are similar and different
compare.example: Don't always compare yourself with others; after all, you're one of a kind.

remain.definition: to continue to be in the same condition
remain.example: When Judy went back to her hometown twenty years later, she found that most things remained unchanged.

provide.definition: to give someone something that he or she needs
provide.example: This hotel provides a nice breakfast and free Wi-Fi for its guests.

pleasant.definition: enjoyable and making one feel happy
pleasant.example: On summer days, it is pleasant to go for a walk in the evening when it is cooler.
